citeinfo.title: Middle Keys Juvenile Snapper Seine Sampling
citeinfo.origin: Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission: Fish and Wildlife Research Institute: Finfish Research Program

pubinfo.publish: Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission-Fish and Wildlife Research Institute

descript.supplinf: Prior to July 1, 2004, the Fish and Wildlife Research Institute (FWRI) was known as the Florida Marine Research Institute (FMRI). The institute name has not been changed in historical data sets or references to work completed by the Florida Marine Research Institute. The institute name has been changed in references to ongoing research, new research, and contact information.
descript.abstract: The FWC: FWRI Finfish Research Program conducted a stratified-random designed study using 21.3m seines on the Atlantic side of the middle Keys in order to collect early life stages of snappers [Gray snapper (Lutjanus griseus), Mutton snapper (Lutjanus analis), Lane snapper (Lutjanus synagris), Schoolmaster snapper (Lutjanus apodus), and Yellowtail snapper (Ocyurus chrysurus)] in shallow near shore seagrass beds adjacent to beach fronts, and to describe their distribution and abundance. Other species abundance information were collected and recorded in conjunction with this sampling effort.
descript.purpose: This long-term seine monitoring program in shallow near shore seagrass beds will attempt to: • Describe the distribution and abundance, species composition, size structure, and habitat usage of juvenile snapper species in the middle Florida Keys • Develop a pre-recruit (juvenile) tuning index which may be used for stock assessments of snapper species.

idinfo.accconst: These data are unrestricted. Where possible, always acquire this dataset directly from FWC as other sources may have altered the original data.
idinfo.useconst: Users are encouraged to read and fully comprehend the metadata record prior to using these data. Please acknowledge the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) as the data source for any products developed from these data. Users should be aware that comparison with other data sets for the same area may be inaccurate due to inconsistencies resulting from changes in mapping conventions, data collection techniques, and computer processes over time. FWC shall not be liable for improper or incorrect use of these data.

dataqual.logic: After visual inspection, these data appear to be logically consistent.
dataqual.complete: These data are complete as of the 9/25/2015 delivery date to Chris Boland from Jeff Renchen, minus the Florida Keys Pilot Project (FKX Survey prefix) and the Marquesas pilot project (MQM Survey prefix).

attracc.attraccr: All attributes appear to be within their intended range or domain.

procstep.procdesc: Data Conversion to Geospatial Data: Jeff Renchen delivered the SeineDB to Chris Boland on 9/25/2015. After delivery, Chris Boland completed the following tasks on the data: 1. Imported the Seine Survey Samples Table (tbl_biology_master) into a GIS compatible personal geodatabase (.mdb) 2. Created a 1-to-many relationship class between MiddleKeys_SeineSurveys_SampleLocs feature class and MiddleKeys_SeineSurveys_Samples table based upon "Survey" Primary-Foreign key pair. 3. Wrote FGDC-CSDGM compliant metadata.

cntperp.cntorg: FWC:FWRI:Information Science & Management: Center for Spatial Analysis

cntinfo.cntinst: Please forward all data requests to GISLibrarian@MyFWC.com.

procstep.procdesc: Field Sampling and Field Data Collection: One seine haul will be conducted during daylight hours at each site. Fish collections will be made using a 21.3m center-bag drag offshore seine, constructed of knotless 3.2mm #35 Delta nylon-mesh and a 183cm x 183cm x 183cm bag. The net coverage area is approximately 140 m2/haul. The seine is pulled by hand using PVC poles attached to the ends of the net. For an offshore seine, the net is set perpendicular to the current or wind (whichever is dominant) in water that is at least 0.3m deep. In order to maintain a standardized distance between the end poles a 15.5m line is attached between the tops of the two end poles and kept taught. In order to standardize the distance of the tow two small PVC tether poles with 9.1m of line attached are anchored in the substrate on both sides of the net adjacent to the end poles, the free end of these tether lines are attached to the end poles. The net is then pulled forward 9.1m until the tether lines become taught. At this point the tether lines are dropped and the seine ends are brought together encircling and trapping the fish. The ends of the net are then pulled together 90o around a pivot pole in order to move the fish down into the bag. Then the bag is slowly inverted and the fish are removed and placed in a 5 gallon bucket for processing. All snappers collected will be counted, measured to the nearest mm, and identified to the lowest possible taxon in the field. This will typically be to species. Young juvenile snapper will be defined as < 100mm standard length (SL), settlement-stage snapper as < 40mm SL, early-stage juveniles as > 20mm to < 40mm SL, and new recruits as < 20mm SL. All other fish collected will be counted, measured, and identified to the lowest possible taxon as well. Hydrographic data, atmospheric and sea conditions, and observations relative to bottom type including water depth, substrate type, submerged aquatic vegetation (SAV) types, and percent bottom cover of SAV will be recorded at each site. Water temperature (ºC), salinity (‰), dissolved oxygen (mg/L), and pH will be measured using a YSI water-quality instrument. Turbidity will be measured using a secchi disk. Four randomly selected seagrass quadrats will be visually surveyed at each site following the Braun-Blanquet technique (Braun-Blanquet, 1972) in order to characterize the abundance, density, and frequency of SAV occurring at the site.

stdorder.fees: None. However, persons or organizations requesting information must provide transfer media if FTP is not available and must pay express shipping costs if express shipping is required.
stdorder.ordering: Contact GIS Librarian by e-mail, telephone, or letter explaining which products are needed and providing a brief description of how the products will be used. Also, provide name and address of the person or organization requesting the products.
stdorder.turnarnd: Usually within 10 business days, although, complex requests may take longer
